subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. I'm making this video on Friday, it's going to be released on
Sunday, July 1st, [2018] and
that's a significant day because if you're watching the news on Sunday,
you’ll notice that a lot of attention is being spent on the election in Mexico.
This may be a very significant event for us in the United States and perhaps for people around the world.
It's not getting a lot of coverage
yet, but it looks like the
new government in Mexico is very likely going to lean far to the left, to be a
hardline socialist government at least. At this moment in time,
it appears that what is being described as a hard-line socialist candidate is [leading]. We may, for all I know,
find a situation
in our neighboring country of Mexico not so different from
Castro's Cuba. Only, Mexico is a much larger country than Cuba ever was and
we share a very long
border with Mexico. So, how this is going to affect the immigration situation
and American
foreign policy,
it's hard to say right now. But, it could be a sign of
trouble ahead if
our neighboring country
elects an
anti-American President. It could happen. Right now, it appears as if it's a very
likely possibility, so it seems as if international tensions may be ratcheting up. Now, I
mention this because there are some videos that are in the New Thinking Allowed
catalog - and if you look in the upper right hand
of your screen right now I'm going to link to the first of those videos. They haven’t been watched very often,
they’re amongst the least
opular of the videos thus far released in the New Thinking Allowed series -
but I regard them highly. They’re videos with the author C.M.
Mayo, that’s her pen name,
actually. But in any case,
I’ve done three interviews with her about Francisco Madero who was the
first
post-revolutionary President of
Mexico. They often refer to him as the leader of the 1910
Revolution. He was elected President of Mexico in 1911, as I recall, and the interesting thing about
Madero is that he was a
spiritualist - very, very clearly.In fact, C.M. Mayo's research suggests he was more than just a
spiritualist, he was a spiritualist medium. In addition,
he was the son of a wealthy landowner and actually published a book, his own book on
spiritualism, published under a pseudonym because he knew that
entering into politics - as he was in a nominally Catholic country - could be problematic for a spiritualist.
Indeed, it was problematic, because he was overthrown and assassinated.
His term of office lasted, I don't know, about a year. But, he is regarded today as
the father of the
Mexican Revolution, a very important historical figure, a person who did a great deal to usher in
more democracy in
Mexico. Now,
he felt that his spiritualist beliefs had an
important role to play in his politics. Even though he tried to keep it hidden,
it was something of an open secret in Mexico City that he was a spiritualist. Some people, such as the
general Victoriano Huerta,
who deposed and assassinated him,
were horrified by the idea of a spiritualist President - that was completely inconsistent with conventional
Catholic theology. They regarded it as something of, I suppose, the best word is an abomination.
But, as I think about it, it seems to me you'll find many other examples of where
esoteric thinkers, whether they're
spiritualists or
Sufis or
kabbalists or
yogis, get involved in politics. There are a variety of
examples: Sri Aurobindo
in India would be another case in point, not to mention Mahatma Gandhi,
a person of deep spiritual values who try to apply those values in a political context. I think
Francisco Madero was one such person. That's why I think it's valuable for
those of you who have an interest in what's going on in Mexico today to take a look at those particular
interviews.
Let me say another thing about Madero: it appears from the
manuscript of his, that C.M. Mayo actually
translated into English and writes about in her book that he believed himself to be in
contact with the spirit of a former President of Mexico, deceased in
Madero’s day: Benito Juarez, who was
regarded as another
democratic reformer, was President of Mexico for many years. It’s as if
Madero
felt that the spirit of Benito Juarez was guiding him to lead a new
revolution because, well, as I understand it, Juarez was the
President, and a Democratic president, under the auspices of what was then known as the Liberal Party in
Mexico. But eventually,
Porfirio Diaz
became President, also President under the Liberal Party,
but he ruled for many, many years as a dictator so there's a fine line between
being a dictator and being an elected President.
There are many examples -
including Mussolini and Hitler - of people who were
elected to office and then used that election as an
opportunity to grab the reins of power and rule like a dictator. So, democracies can be readily
subverted.
Of course, it raises a number of questions to think about.
Was there an esoteric, a spiritual component to
history?
Has that happened? Are the Illuminati or the Hidden Masters
operating behind the scenes to
influence politics? Or are there other influences? I don't know. I'm sure many people think there are Satanic
influences. Other people think that it's, you know, all sorts of conspiracies and Cabals.
But, what about genuine…
I’m searching for a word... higher consciousness,
entities of a higher
consciousness attempting to influence history? I mean, that is in effect the story of the Bible
where God…
God
influences history.
One wonders, is it for the better or not? God who freed the Jews from slavery in Egypt and
established
under his auspices the kingdom of… the ancient kingdom of Israel and
has influenced history in many other ways.
So, we have this thread in our culture whether it is Jehovah or Yahweh,
the deity of the Hebrew Bible, or whether it is
esoteric sources of a spiritualist nature, or whether it is great yogis and illuminated beings,
Buddhas. There's a long history of
spiritual leaders,
whether they're incarnate or disincarnate, playing a role in politics. Then we can ask:
Well, what's the outcome of that, is it good?
Did Francisco
Madero’s
intervention in Mexico
really lead to progress? Or, is progress so slow and incremental
that it's hardly noticeable? Or, is it a question of taking two steps forward and three steps back?
How do we judge human progress? If there is a
spiritual hierarchy that has an interest in human affairs
but doesn't want to violate the
great commandment [Prime Directive] of Star Trek not to intervene
in other planets’
activities,
how does that work? How does that operate? I'm inclined to think it doesn't always work out for the best.
I'm not sure. Certainly it didn't for Francisco Madero, who was assassinated. Then people
may say, “Yes, but so he was assassinated, he’s still regarded as the father of the Mexican Revolution.”
But then, what became of the Mexican Revolution?
What does all of this mean to us today?
How can we
be as
vigilant as possible regarding the shifting sands of politics?
Because
obviously things change dramatically - where one stands today may not be where one wishes to stand tomorrow.
What is the role of spirituality in
politics? What is the role of higher consciousness in
politics? Is there a legitimate role or should they be
separate? Does nothing positive come from mixing
politics and consciousness?
These are all food for thought.
I'll leave you with those
unanswered questions. Thank you for being with me.
